MethodPlugin.name: software_process_example
MethodPlugin.authors: Ed Werner, Cervantes Hernandez Moreira, Gourav Acharya, Talal Alsarrani

ContentElement.name: schedule_and_assign_tasks
ContentElement.briefDescription: Developing a schedule for the work to be undertaken for this software change, and assigning individual tasks to specific staff members: specifically, a design engineer and a quality assurance (QA) engineer. The design review is also scheduled, and participants are assigned to it; the participants will be the design and QA engineer, along with two other software engineers.

Presentation.name: ,_4m8pEA0KEeiMmoWQJFO3CQ
Presentation.MainDescription: This step is a project management function, and is the first step carried out in this process. It involves developing a schedule for the work to be undertaken for this software change, and assigning individual tasks to specific staff members: specifically, a design engineer and a quality assurance (QA) engineer. The design review is also scheduled, and participants are assigned to it; the participants will be the design and QA engineer, along with two other software engineers.

Section.name: Develop a schedule for the work to be undertaken for this software change
Schedule design review
Assign tasks for the design engineer
Assign tasks for the QA engineer
Assign two software engineers

Presentation.Purpose: To focus on assignment of resources to the tasks and estimation of the schedule required for those resources to carry out the tasks.

ContentElement.name: review_design
ContentElement.briefDescription: This step involves the formal review of the modified design.

Presentation.name: review_design,_-y2xsA0KEeiMmoWQJFO3CQ
Presentation.MainDescription:
This step involves the formal review of the modified design. It is conducted by a team including the design engineer who produced the design modifications. There are three alternative outcomes of the review:

     1) Unconditional approval - The design is totally approved; the approved modified design is incorporated into the software design document.

     2) Minor changes recommended - Minor changes to the design are required and feedback is provided to the designer. The re-review is expected to be perfunctory.

     3) Major changes recommended - Major changes to the design are requred and feedback is provided to the designer.

At the conclusion of the review, the project manager is notified of the outcome. Due to the fact that formal design reviews are a relatively new step in this organization’s process, they are recording certain measurements to help evaluate its impact, In particular, the number of defects identified, and the aggregate effort of the review team in preparing for and conducting the review are reported to the project manager.

Section.name: Review modified design
Include number of defects identified and aggregate effort of review team in review
Notify project manager of outcome at conclusion of review

ContentElement.name: modify_code
ContentElement.briefDescription: This step involves the implementation of the design changes into code, and compilation of the modified source code into object code.

Presentation.name: modify_code,_BEbLsA0LEeiMmoWQJFO3CQ
Presentation.MainDescription: This step involves the implementation of the design changes into code, and compilation of the modified source code into object code. Implementation is accomplished by modifying existing source code. This step may also be based upon feedback from testing, indicating that additional source code modifications are required.

Section.name: Implement design changes in code
Compile modified source code into object code
Complete additional source code modifications based on testing feedback

Presentation.Purpose: To implement design changes in code.

ContentElement.name: modify_test_plans
ContentElement.briefDescription: This step involves the modification of test plans and objectives to include testing of capabilities related to the requirements change prompting this software modification.

Presentation.name: modify_test_plans,_DStBIA0LEeiMmoWQJFO3CQ
Presentation.MainDescription: This step involves the modification of test plans and objectives to include testing of capabilities related to the requirements change prompting this software modification. These test plans are analogous to software designs. They identify the functionality and capabilities to be tested, and the approach to be taken. On the other hand, the specifics of actual test data, procedures, and so forth are dealt with in the subsequent step (modify unit test package).

Section.name: Modification of test plans and objectives
Identify functionality and capabilities to be tested
Identify approach to be taken for testing
Test capabilities related to requirements change

Presentation.Purpose: Modify test plans and objectives based on requirements change.

ContentElement.name: modify_unit_test_package
ContentElement.briefDescription: This step involves the modification of test plans and objectives to include testing of capabilities related to the requirements change prompting this software modification.

Presentation.name: modify_unit_test_package,_FscfsA0LEeiMmoWQJFO3CQ
Presentation.MainDescription: This step involves the modification of the actual unit test package for the affected code unit, in accordance with the modifications made to the test plans and objectives. It will be assumed that the test package contains computer software to drive and evaluate the unit under test, along with narrative procedures recorded in accompanying computer files. These test packages are under automated configuration management, and a new version of the unit test package is created when this step ends. Finally, it is noted that the modified design and/or the source code for this unit may be used as input to this step; however, this is not always the case. Subsequent iterations of this step may be based upon feedback from testing, indicating that additional modifications to the unit test package are required.

Section.name: Comply with modifications made to the test plans and objective
Use modified design and/or source code for this unit as input
Modify the actual unit test package for the affected code unit

Presentation.Purpose: Modify test unit package for affected code unit based on modifications of test plans and objectives.

ContentElement.name: test_unit
ContentElement.briefDescription: This step involves the application of the unit test package on the modified code, and analysis of the results. Both the design and QA engineers participate in this step.

Presentation.name: test_unit,_IiffwA0LEeiMmoWQJFO3CQ
Presentation.MainDescription:
This step involves the application of the unit test package on the modified code, and analysis of the results. Both the design and QA engineers participate in this step. The entire test package is run before any analysis or further action is taken. Although the unit tests are primarily functional, an automated coverage analyzer is employed to determine that adequate test coverage of the unit’s code has been achieved; a 90% threshold has been established as acceptable. If all tests are successfully completed, and 90% coverage attained, then the unit has successfully passed. When this is not the case, the design and QA engineers jointly analyze the test results and determine appropriate actions. In order to confine the problem, assume that either or both of the following are the outcomes of this analysis: the source code needs to be modified further, the unit tests need to be modified further. When the indicated modifications have been made, the unit can be retested.

If the unit passes its tests and meets an acceptable coverage level, then this example process has been completed. Steps beyond unit testing, such as integration testing, are beyond the scope of the core problem. The project manager is notified that the latest version of the unit code is available for integration testing.

Constraints:

1) This step can begin as soon as both the object code and unit test package are available.

2) This step ends when its outputs have been provided; assume that all outputs are produced simultaneously.

Section.name: Apply unit test package on modified code
Run entire test package before analysis or further action is taken
Employ test coverage analyzer to determine adequate coverage (90%)
Design and QA engineers jointly analyze test results
Determine actions when insufficient coverage is discovered
Modify source code if insufficient coverage is discovered
Modify unit tests if insufficient coverage is discovered
Re-run unit tests after changes are made
Notify project manager that latest version of the unit code is available for integration testing

Presentation.Purpose: Apply unit test package on modified code.

ContentElement.name: monitor_progress
ContentElement.briefDescription: This step involves the project manager monitoring progress and status of the work

Presentation.name: monitor_progress,_KM2v0A0LEeiMmoWQJFO3CQ
Presentation.MainDescription: This step involves the project manager monitoring progress and status of the work. This is based upon notification of completion of each step, as well as informal information. While work proceeds according to plan, no action is taken and no output is developed by this step. On the other hand, deviations from plan can result in rescheduling of tasks. In severe cases, the project manager may put the entire modification effort on hold, and recommend to the CCB that this change effort be canceled. The CCB may either concur and cancel the effort, or indicate that it is to be resumed where it left off. In such cases the affected personnel are notified (by the project manager) as appropriate regarding the resumption or cancellation of their work on this change.

Section.name: Monitor progress and status of work
Reschedule tasks due to deviations
Put the entire modification effort on hold (in severe cases)
Recommend to the CCB that this change effort be canceled (in severe cases)

Presentation.Purpose: To monitor progress and status of work.

ContentElement.name: requirements_change
ContentElement.briefDescription: Although

Presentation.name: new_guideline,_BCWjMBGtEeifx6UZyY1EkQ
Presentation.MainDescription:
2.3. Develop Change and Test Unit

2.3.1. Description

This step is a high-level abstraction of the process described in this core problem. The details are described in the remainder of the core problem description. It is intended that solutions show this high-level abstraction as well as its decomposition into the details.

2.3.2. Inputs

1) Requirements change (from CCB) (hand carried)

2) Authorization (from CCB) (verbal)

2.3.3. Outputs

1) No explicit output flow. The final results are available in various files or databases and comprise the modified software unit in various representations (design, source code, object code) and its associated modified unit tests. These are all available to subsequent steps in the software life cycle.   

2.3.4. Responsibility

This step is carried out by the project team.

2.3.5. Constraints

1) This step can begin as soon as authorization to make the change has been granted by the CCB.

2) This step ends when the unit testing has been successfully completed, or when the CCB cancels the change effort.

ContentElement.name: modified_source_code
ContentElement.briefDescription: To software development files, computer I/O

ContentElement.name: updated_project_plans
ContentElement.briefDescription: To file, computer I/O

ContentElement.name: notification_of_revised_task_assignments_and_scheduled_dates
ContentElement.presentationName: Notification of revised task assignments and scheduled dates

ContentElement.name: modify_design
ContentElement.briefDescription: This step involves the modification of the design for the code unit affected by the requirements change.

Presentation.name: modify_design,_ZPjZwBZdEei-X60GZyOg_w
Presentation.MainDescription: This step involves the modification of the design for the code unit affected by the requirements change. It is a highly creative task. The modified design will be reviewed, and ultimately implemented in code. This step may also modify the design based upon feedback from the design review.

Section.name: Modify design based on requirements change
Modify design based on design review feedback

Presentation.Purpose: Modify design for code unit based on requirements change.

ContentElement.name: review_design_details
ContentElement.briefDescription: Developing the details of the review design step more fully.

Presentation.name: ,_phw4cBZnEei-X60GZyOg_w
Presentation.MainDescription: Develop the details of the review design step more fully. This step is one carried out by a group of engineers, and involves considerable inter-personal communication, collaboration, and cooperation. Further elaboration of this step would deal with the dynamics of how such a group review process occurs. Any reasonable design review procedures may be assumed to incorporate this extension.
Presentation.Purpose: To fully develop details of design review.

ContentElement.name: additional_information_for_unit_test_package
ContentElement.briefDescription: Additional information for the task 'unit test package'
ContentElement.presentationName: Additional information for unit test package

Presentation.name: new_guideline,_J-SEMBYSEei7tO_70BPhqA
Presentation.MainDescription:
Each instance of the unit test package include:-


1. Software


2. Procedures


3.Timestamp


4.Version Information


5.Engineer responsible for this package instance

ContentElement.name: configuration_management
ContentElement.briefDescription: This text contains some additional information for the Modify Code task.

Presentation.name: configuration_management,_ghDf0BYNEei7tO_70BPhqA
Presentation.MainDescription:
This step deals with a set of objects (entities) whose attributes and interrelationships need to be recorded. Both source and object code are under automated configuration management. The latest version of the software unit’s source code provides the starting point for modification during this step.

Upon successful compilation, a new version of the unit’s source code is recorded, along with its corresponding object code. In addition, these must be related to the modified design upon which they are based. Source code information includes the body, creation timestamp, version information, and engineer responsible for this change.   Object code information includes the body, target system, and creation timestamp. Each source code instance can have multiple corresponding object code instances. Similarly, each design version can relate to multiple source code instances.

 For each successful compilation of a given source code  instance, it is important  to  record the  timestamp,  the  compiler  version  used, all compiler options selected  (e.g., optimizer on,  debugging on), any error or warning messages produced, and listings and associated documentation such as memory maps.

ContentElement.name: detailed_steps_to_modify_code
ContentElement.briefDescription: A detailed analysis of what happens during the modification of code.

Presentation.name: detailed_steps_to_modify_code,_yT5DwBYXEei7tO_70BPhqA
Presentation.MainDescription:
1. Direct modifications are made to the source code by the engineer, while object code is produced by compiler.


2. The current source code (latest version) is withdrawn from the configuration management library at the outset of this step.


3. The engineer invokes an editor to make his changes to the source code. When he decides that the source code is ready for   compilation, he saves the source code file and invokes the compiler on it.


4. If there are compilation errors, he goes back to the source code to make additional modifications and then recompile.


5. If a clean compilation has been achieved before the design has been approved, a final manual check of the code is made by the engineer after the design is approved and before the code is released for unit testing; this may result in additional source code changes.


6. It may be convenient (although not required) to assume that intermediate versions of the code objects and compilation information and products are maintained in a private library (database) under configuration (version) management. Only the final version needs to be placed into the software development files.

ContentElement.name: example_process
ContentElement.briefDescription: A concise description of how the work in the process is being performed.

Presentation.name: example_process,_XGZc4BYFEei7tO_70BPhqA
Presentation.MainDescription:
Here's a brief description of how the Software process flows and how tasks are performed: 

  1. A change in requirements is requested, presumably by the customer, late into the development or support ( maintenance  and enhancements) phase of the process. 

  1. If the  CCB ( Configuration Control Board) analyses and approves the change then the Project manager starts scheduling and assigning tasks to ultimately carry out the change in the code unit affected. 

  1. These tasks  include:- 

  • Modify Design  

  • Review Design  

  • Modify Code 

  • Modify Test Plans 

  • Modify Unit Test Package  

  • Test Unit  

  • Monitor Progress  

  1. Even though "Modify code" and "Modify plans" are scheduled in parallel with the other tasks, it would not be ideal to have these tasks move forward without the design being reviewed and the code modified respectively. 

  1. First, the design is  modified  and sent for design review conducted by the currently new task for the  organization  called "Review Design". 

  1. If the design is approved, the code is modified under the "Modify code" task. Otherwise Modify design task keeps iterating until design is accepted. 

  1. Once code is modified appropriately, new test plans are  drafted,  or old ones are modified to verify its  behavior ( "Modify test plans").  

  1. This leads to the modification of the unit test package which  must  be modified to test the code modification. 

  1. Then comes the "Test unit" task which   involves the application  of  the  unit  test  package  on the  modified code,  and  analysis  of  the  results .  

  1. Once the unit test passes and meets the appropriate coverage levels the Software process is deemed completed.

ContentElement.name: base_constraint
ContentElement.briefDescription: Contrain for the task

Presentation.name: base_constraint,_pqtUEBaeEeiP8KYb2COzmg
Presentation.MainDescription: Contraint for the tasks.

Presentation.name: modify_code_constraints,_pqtUERaeEeiP8KYb2COzmg
Presentation.MainDescription:
1. This step can begin as soon as the task has been assigned by the project manager. (Thus, it is possible, if not advisable, to begin coding before the design work has even begun.) The engineer’s discretion determines when this task will actually commence, if the design has not yet been approved. If this step has not commenced earlier, it will begin when the design is approved.

2. Modified code released for testing is to reflect the approved modified design. One consequence is that this step cannot be completed before the modified design has been approved.

3. This step ends when a clean compilation (no errors) has been accomplished and its output has been provided.


4. Subsequent iterations (if required) can begin as soon as the test unit step has completed .

Presentation.name: modify_design_constraints,_pqtUEhaeEeiP8KYb2COzmg
Presentation.MainDescription:
1. This step can begin as soon as the task has been assigned by the project manager.
2. Subsequent iterations can begin as soon as the design review is completed (when the design is not approved).
3. This step ends when its output has been provided.

Presentation.name: modify_test_plans_constraints,_pqtUExaeEeiP8KYb2COzmg
Presentation.MainDescription:
1. This step can begin as soon as the task has been assigned by the project manager.
2. This step ends when its output has been provided.

Presentation.name: modify_unit_test_package_constraints,_pqtUFBaeEeiP8KYb2COzmg
Presentation.MainDescription:
1. This step can begin as soon as the modify test plans step has completed.
2. This step ends when its output has been produced.
3. Subsequent iterations (if required) can begin as soon as the test unit step has completed.

Presentation.name: monitor_progress_constraints,_pqtUFRaeEeiP8KYb2COzmg
Presentation.MainDescription:
1. This step can begin as soon as the initial task, schedule and assign tasks, is completed.
2. This step persists throughout the duration of this process. For the purposes of this example, assume that this task ends (1) when the unit testing has been successfully completed, or (2) after notifying personnel of cancellation by the CCB.

Presentation.name: review_design_constraints,_pqtUFhaeEeiP8KYb2COzmg
Presentation.MainDescription:
1. This step will be carried out when it is scheduled to occur, provided that the modified design is available at that time. (Note that in cases of delay, the monitor progress step will reschedule the review to a later date.)
2. This step ends when its outputs have been provided; assume that all outputs are produced simultaneously.

Presentation.name: schedule_and_assign_task_constraints,_pqtUFxaeEeiP8KYb2COzmg
Presentation.MainDescription:
1. This step can begin as soon as authorization to make the change is granted by the CCB.
2. This step ends when its outputs have been provided; assume that all outputs are produced simultaneously.

Presentation.name: test_unit_constraints,_pqt7IBaeEeiP8KYb2COzmg
Presentation.MainDescription:
1. This step can begin as soon as both the object code and unit test package are available.
2. This step ends when its outputs have been provided; assume that all outputs are produced
simultaneously.

Process.name: Develop Change and Test Unit 2.0
Process.briefDescription: The complete process for changing sourcecode and testing.

Presentation.name: Develop Change and Test Unit 2.0,_zCRn4RKiEei_JOWs6zR2NA
Presentation.MainDescription: Given a Requirements change this process will be carried out to make that change possible.
Presentation.KeyConsiderations:
Constraints.

1.This step can begin as soon as authorization to make the change has been granted by the CCB.

2. This step ends when the unit testing has been successfully completed, or when the CCB cancels the change effort.

This step involves the formal review of the modified design. It is conducted by a team including the design engineer who produced the design modifications. There are three alternative outcomes of the review:

     1) Unconditional approval - The design is totally approved; the approved modified design is incorporated into the software design document.

     2) Minor changes recommended - Minor changes to the design are required and feedback is provided to the designer. The re-review is expected to be perfunctory.

     3) Major changes recommended - Major changes to the design are requred and feedback is provided to the designer.

At the conclusion of the review, the project manager is notified of the outcome. Due to the fact that formal design reviews are a relatively new step in this organization’s process, they are recording certain measurements to help evaluate its impact, In particular, the number of defects identified, and the aggregate effort of the review team in preparing for and conducting the review are reported to the project manager.

This step involves the application of the unit test package on the modified code, and analysis of the results. Both the design and QA engineers participate in this step. The entire test package is run before any analysis or further action is taken. Although the unit tests are primarily functional, an automated coverage analyzer is employed to determine that adequate test coverage of the unit’s code has been achieved; a 90% threshold has been established as acceptable. If all tests are successfully completed, and 90% coverage attained, then the unit has successfully passed. When this is not the case, the design and QA engineers jointly analyze the test results and determine appropriate actions. In order to confine the problem, assume that either or both of the following are the outcomes of this analysis: the source code needs to be modified further, the unit tests need to be modified further. When the indicated modifications have been made, the unit can be retested.

If the unit passes its tests and meets an acceptable coverage level, then this example process has been completed. Steps beyond unit testing, such as integration testing, are beyond the scope of the core problem. The project manager is notified that the latest version of the unit code is available for integration testing.

Constraints:

1) This step can begin as soon as both the object code and unit test package are available.

2) This step ends when its outputs have been provided; assume that all outputs are produced simultaneously.

Step.name: Apply unit test package on modified code
Run entire test package before analysis or further action is taken
Employ test coverage analyzer to determine adequate coverage (90%)
Design and QA engineers jointly analyze test results
Determine actions when insufficient coverage is discovered
Modify source code if insufficient coverage is discovered
Modify unit tests if insufficient coverage is discovered
Re-run unit tests after changes are made
Notify project manager that latest version of the unit code is available for integration testing

BreakdownElement.name: unit_test_package
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From test package file, computer I/O

BreakdownElement.name: notification_of_completion
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From all technical tasks, via e-mail

BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From file, computer I/O

BreakdownElement.name: Develop Change and Test Unit 2.0
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: The complete process for changing sourcecode and testing.

Presentation.name: Develop Change and Test Unit 2.0,_zCRn4RKiEei_JOWs6zR2NA
Presentation.MainDescription: Given a Requirements change this process will be carried out to make that change possible.
Presentation.KeyConsiderations:
Constraints.

1.This step can begin as soon as authorization to make the change has been granted by the CCB.

2. This step ends when the unit testing has been successfully completed, or when the CCB cancels the change effort.

BreakdownElement.name: authorization
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: from CCB, verbal

BreakdownElement.name: requirements_change
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: Although

BreakdownElement.name: schedule_and_assign_tasks
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: Developing a schedule for the work to be undertaken for this software change, and assigning individual tasks to specific staff members: specifically, a design engineer and a quality assurance (QA) engineer. The design review is also scheduled, and participants are assigned to it; the participants will be the design and QA engineer, along with two other software engineers.

Presentation.name: schedule_and_assign_tasks,_t5gh0BKjEei_JOWs6zR2NA
Presentation.RefinedDescription: This step is a project management function, and is the first step carried out in this process. It involves developing a schedule for the work to be undertaken for this software change, and assigning individual tasks to specific staff members: specifically, a design engineer and a quality assurance (QA) engineer. The design review is also scheduled, and participants are assigned to it; the participants will be the design and QA engineer, along with two other software engineers.

Step.name: Develop a schedule for the work to be undertaken for this software change
Schedule design review
Assign tasks for the design engineer
Assign tasks for the QA engineer
Assign two software engineers

BreakdownElement.name: design_review_feedback
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: To modify design, hand carried

BreakdownElement.name: modified_design
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From modify design, hand carried

BreakdownElement.name: outcome_notification_number_of_defects_identified_aggregate_effort
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From review design, e-mail
BreakdownElement.presentationName: Outcome notification, number of defects identified, aggregate effort

BreakdownElement.name: notification_of_completion
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From all technical tasks, via e-mail

BreakdownElement.name: modify_design
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: This step involves the modification of the design for the code unit affected by the requirements change.

Presentation.name: modify_design,_zeNNcBapEeiIf8YthU0UvA
Presentation.RefinedDescription: This step involves the modification of the design for the code unit affected by the requirements change. It is a highly creative task. The modified design will be reviewed, and ultimately implemented in code. This step may also modify the design based upon feedback from the design review.

Step.name: Modify design based on requirements change
Modify design based on design review feedback

BreakdownElement.name: review_design
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: This step involves the formal review of the modified design.

Presentation.name: review_design,_Jgk8UBWVEeiy1JjwJG5oCw
Presentation.RefinedDescription:
This step involves the formal review of the modified design. It is conducted by a team including the design engineer who produced the design modifications. There are three alternative outcomes of the review:

     1) Unconditional approval - The design is totally approved; the approved modified design is incorporated into the software design document.

     2) Minor changes recommended - Minor changes to the design are required and feedback is provided to the designer. The re-review is expected to be perfunctory.

     3) Major changes recommended - Major changes to the design are requred and feedback is provided to the designer.

At the conclusion of the review, the project manager is notified of the outcome. Due to the fact that formal design reviews are a relatively new step in this organization’s process, they are recording certain measurements to help evaluate its impact, In particular, the number of defects identified, and the aggregate effort of the review team in preparing for and conducting the review are reported to the project manager.

Step.name: Review modified design
Include number of defects identified and aggregate effort of review team in review
Notify project manager of outcome at conclusion of review

BreakdownElement.name: current_design
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From software design document file, hand carried

BreakdownElement.name: current_test_plans
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From test plans file, hand carried

BreakdownElement.name: modified_test_plans
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From test plans file, hand carried

BreakdownElement.name: modify_test_plans
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: This step involves the modification of test plans and objectives to include testing of capabilities related to the requirements change prompting this software modification.

Presentation.name: modify_test_plans,_GlXS8BWWEeiy1JjwJG5oCw
Presentation.RefinedDescription: This step involves the modification of test plans and objectives to include testing of capabilities related to the requirements change prompting this software modification. These test plans are analogous to software designs. They identify the functionality and capabilities to be tested, and the approach to be taken. On the other hand, the specifics of actual test data, procedures, and so forth are dealt with in the subsequent step (modify unit test package).

Step.name: Modification of test plans and objectives
Identify functionality and capabilities to be tested
Identify approach to be taken for testing
Test capabilities related to requirements change

BreakdownElement.name: notification_of_completion
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From all technical tasks, via e-mail

BreakdownElement.name: current_project_plans
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From file, computer I/O

BreakdownElement.name: outcome_notification_number_of_defects_identified_aggregate_effort
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From review design, e-mail
BreakdownElement.presentationName: Outcome notification, number of defects identified, aggregate effort

BreakdownElement.name: updated_project_plans
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: To file, computer I/O

BreakdownElement.name: notification_of_revised_task_assignments_and_scheduled_dates
BreakdownElement.presentationName: Notification of revised task assignments and scheduled dates

BreakdownElement.name: modify_unit_test_package
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: This step involves the modification of test plans and objectives to include testing of capabilities related to the requirements change prompting this software modification.

Presentation.name: modify_unit_test_package,_6vS1cBapEeiIf8YthU0UvA
Presentation.RefinedDescription: This step involves the modification of the actual unit test package for the affected code unit, in accordance with the modifications made to the test plans and objectives. It will be assumed that the test package contains computer software to drive and evaluate the unit under test, along with narrative procedures recorded in accompanying computer files. These test packages are under automated configuration management, and a new version of the unit test package is created when this step ends. Finally, it is noted that the modified design and/or the source code for this unit may be used as input to this step; however, this is not always the case. Subsequent iterations of this step may be based upon feedback from testing, indicating that additional modifications to the unit test package are required.

Step.name: Comply with modifications made to the test plans and objective
Use modified design and/or source code for this unit as input
Modify the actual unit test package for the affected code unit

BreakdownElement.name: monitor_progress
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: This step involves the project manager monitoring progress and status of the work

Presentation.name: monitor_progress,_PNm7IBWWEeiy1JjwJG5oCw
Presentation.RefinedDescription: This step involves the project manager monitoring progress and status of the work. This is based upon notification of completion of each step, as well as informal information. While work proceeds according to plan, no action is taken and no output is developed by this step. On the other hand, deviations from plan can result in rescheduling of tasks. In severe cases, the project manager may put the entire modification effort on hold, and recommend to the CCB that this change effort be canceled. The CCB may either concur and cancel the effort, or indicate that it is to be resumed where it left off. In such cases the affected personnel are notified (by the project manager) as appropriate regarding the resumption or cancellation of their work on this change.

Step.name: Monitor progress and status of work
Reschedule tasks due to deviations
Put the entire modification effort on hold (in severe cases)
Recommend to the CCB that this change effort be canceled (in severe cases)

BreakdownElement.briefDescription: From modify design, hand carried

BreakdownElement.name: modify_code
BreakdownElement.briefDescription: This step involves the implementation of the design changes into code, and compilation of the modified source code into object code.

Presentation.name: modify_code,_PRQGMBWwEeiy1JjwJG5oCw
Presentation.RefinedDescription: This step involves the implementation of the design changes into code, and compilation of the modified source code into object code. Implementation is accomplished by modifying existing source code. This step may also be based upon feedback from testing, indicating that additional source code modifications are required.

Step.name: Implement design changes in code
Compile modified source code into object code
Complete additional source code modifications based on testing feedback

BreakdownElement.name: test_unit

Presentation.name: test_unit,_QCKlwBWwEeiy1JjwJG5oCw
Presentation.RefinedDescription:
This step involves the application of the unit test package on the modified code, and analysis of the results. Both the design and QA engineers participate in this step. The entire test package is run before any analysis or further action is taken. Although the unit tests are primarily functional, an automated coverage analyzer is employed to determine that adequate test coverage of the unit’s code has been achieved; a 90% threshold has been established as acceptable. If all tests are successfully completed, and 90% coverage attained, then the unit has successfully passed. When this is not the case, the design and QA engineers jointly analyze the test results and determine appropriate actions. In order to confine the problem, assume that either or both of the following are the outcomes of this analysis: the source code needs to be modified further, the unit tests need to be modified further. When the indicated modifications have been made, the unit can be retested.

If the unit passes its tests and meets an acceptable coverage level, then this example process has been completed. Steps beyond unit testing, such as integration testing, are beyond the scope of the core problem. The project manager is notified that the latest version of the unit code is available for integration testing.

Constraints:

1) This step can begin as soon as both the object code and unit test package are available.

2) This step ends when its outputs have been provided; assume that all outputs are produced simultaneously.

Step.name: Apply unit test package on modified code
Run entire test package before analysis or further action is taken
Employ test coverage analyzer to determine adequate coverage (90%)
Design and QA engineers jointly analyze test results
Determine actions when insufficient coverage is discovered
